Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Nanoscale Cues for Regenerative Neural Cell Systems
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project the PI will investigate the hypothesis that there is a fundamental set of nanoscale physical and biochemical properties that serve as the primary cues for the re-establishment of cell systems that rely on nanofibrillar scaffolds in their native environment, and they will use an integrated approach for their investigation. A novel investigative tool, scanning probe recognition microscopy, will be used in concert with state of the art immunocytochemistry, fluorescent microscopy and blot techniques in an integrated physics-cell biology effort that links the physical properties at the nanoscale with important cellular responses. Results from this research are likely to have a major impact on regenerative medicine aimed at recreating the neural cell system following central nervous system injury. Furthermore, as cell systems that are influenced by scaffold-based environments are ubiquitous throughout the body, identification of the fundamental set of nanoscale properties that promote healthy neural cell physiology and function, serves as the basis for the quantitative exploration of other regenerative cell-scaffold systems. The research program will be realized with active student participation. Regular exchange visits, joint training, and regular communication, with evaluation and dissemination of results, will contribute to the multidisciplinary training. The proposed pipeline program for the introduction of traditionally underrepresented undergraduates within the research, in collaboration with the mentored MI-LSAMP and RISE programs, will build on the PI,s successful experiences with both.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is great promise and excitement in the field of regenerative medicine resulting from experimental observations that when injury sites are supplied with scaffold-based bridge environments that are physically and biochemically mimetic for the native environment, native and/or introduced cells such as pluripotent stem cells can regenerate and re-establish functional connections with healthy surrounding tissue.  Until recently, biomaterials and scaffolds have been mainly viewed as passive delivery vehicles  for cell and pharmacological therapies. Recent research, however, strongly indicates that they are capable of supplying directive physical cues in their own right that work in conjunction with ambient biochemical cues and produce a jointly-directed outcome. These are nanoscale cues as cellular receptors are nanoscale sensors. Knowledgeable use of the nanophysical cues presented by therapeutic scaffolds, therefore, offers new and under-utilized biomaterials-based strategy for positive intervention.

A biomaterial scaffold does not present only one feature or property to cells, but rather, a complex set of properties. In Physics of Living Systems 0957776, we have succeeded in quantitatively investigating the nanoscale elasticity, surface roughness, charge and work of adhesion for an implantable scaffold composed of electrospun polyamide nanofibers that has demonstrated promise in two separate rat model spinal cord injury studies. Repair of traumatic injury to the central nervous system (CNS: brain and spinal cord) remains a challenging problem for both patients and care-providers. One of the hurdles that must be overcome is the glial scar, which is established after traumatic injury and creates a barrier to regeneration of neurons. Neurons are well known for their vital functions in cognition, memory, and emotion. Astrocytes are less well known but equally vital support cells for neurons – so important that the ratio of astrocytes/neurons in humans is 5:1.  Astrocytes are the cells that respond to CNS injuries by sealing off the wound site. Reactive astrocytes at a wound site undergo a morphological change, extending interwoven processes that form chain-like clusters, while expressing inhibitory proteoglycans that destroy approaching neuron growth cones. The result is a glial scar that biomechanically and biochemically blocks neuron reconnection.

The nanoscale cues presented by the promising nanofibrillar scaffolds (NFS) were investigated first versus three controls (Fig. 1): poly-L-lysine functionalized glass (PLLG), a standard neural cell culture surface, Aclar (ACL) and PLL-functionalized Aclar (PLLA). PLLA and ACL were originally studied to clarify elasticity and surface functionalization issues; however, the fortuitous investigation of non-standard culture surfaces revealed much more.

Novel atomic force microscopy developed by the PI yielded statistically meaningful amounts of data for each nanoscale property. Pairwise comparisons using ANOVA with Tukey’s test demonstrated that the surfaces presented significantly different sets of properties to cells (Fig. 2A). A novel conversion of representative statistical data into four-dimensional attribute data enabled cluster analysis (Fig. 2B) that demonstrated the degree to which each substrate presented a quantitatively different directive environment. The distinctiveness of these environments when considered as sets of nanophysical properties came as a surprise.
